domain.name: Asbestos and Talc Litigation - Genomics and Cancer Causation
domain.description: Scientific, medical, and regulatory literature monitoring for legal defense teams representing asbestos and talc defendants, with specialized focus on genomic research related to cancer causation, predisposition, and susceptibility

topics.name: Mesothelioma - Genomic Predisposition
topics.description: Genetic and genomic factors in mesothelioma development, including susceptibility genes, somatic mutations, and molecular pathways
topics.rationale: Primary focus area - directly impacts causation arguments and alternative causation theories in asbestos litigation

topics.name: Asbestos Exposure and Genetic Susceptibility
topics.description: Individual genetic variations that modify risk of disease following asbestos exposure
topics.rationale: Critical for establishing whether genetic factors contribute to disease independent of or in addition to exposure

topics.name: Talc Exposure and Genetic Susceptibility
topics.description: Genetic factors influencing disease risk following talc exposure
topics.rationale: Essential for talc litigation defense and causation analysis

topics.name: Cancer Genomics - Other Cancers
topics.description: Genomic research on cancers other than mesothelioma potentially linked to asbestos or talc
topics.rationale: Secondary focus - relevant to expanded litigation contexts

topics.name: Germline Mutations and Cancer Predisposition
topics.description: Inherited genetic variants that increase baseline cancer risk independent of environmental exposures
topics.rationale: Key to alternative causation arguments - demonstrates non-exposure pathways to disease

topics.name: Somatic Mutations and Cancer Development
topics.description: Acquired genetic changes during lifetime that drive cancer progression
topics.rationale: Helps distinguish exposure-related from spontaneous or alternative-cause mutations

topics.name: BAP1 and Tumor Suppressor Genes
topics.description: Research on BAP1 and other tumor suppressor genes implicated in mesothelioma and related cancers
topics.rationale: BAP1 mutations are established mesothelioma risk factors independent of asbestos exposure

topics.name: DNA Repair Mechanisms
topics.description: Genetic variations in DNA repair pathways affecting carcinogen response
topics.rationale: Influences individual susceptibility to environmental carcinogens and spontaneous mutations

topics.name: Epigenetics and Gene Expression
topics.description: Epigenetic modifications and gene expression changes in cancer development
topics.rationale: Emerging area showing non-genetic mechanisms of cancer development

topics.name: Exposure Biomarkers and Genomics
topics.description: Genetic and molecular markers of asbestos or talc exposure
topics.rationale: Helps establish or refute exposure claims through biological evidence

topics.name: Alternative Causation Theories
topics.description: Non-exposure mechanisms and alternative etiologies for claimed cancers
topics.rationale: Central to defense strategy - establishing alternative explanations for disease

topics.name: Dose-Response Relationships
topics.description: Research on exposure thresholds, dose-response curves, and minimum exposure requirements
topics.rationale: Critical for challenging causation claims in low-exposure scenarios

entities.name: Malignant Mesothelioma
entities.context: Primary disease of interest in asbestos litigation

entities.name: Lung Cancer
entities.context: Secondary cancer relevant to asbestos exposure claims

entities.name: Ovarian Cancer
entities.context: Primary cancer relevant to talc litigation

entities.name: BAP1
entities.context: Key tumor suppressor gene; germline mutations strongly associated with mesothelioma predisposition

entities.name: NF2
entities.context: Tumor suppressor frequently mutated in mesothelioma

entities.name: Talc
entities.context: Primary exposure substance in talc litigation

entities.name: CDKN2A
entities.context: Tumor suppressor commonly deleted in mesothelioma

entities.name: DNA Repair Pathways
entities.context: Genetic pathways affecting susceptibility to carcinogen-induced damage

entities.name: Whole Exome Sequencing
entities.context: Key methodology for identifying germline and somatic mutations

entities.name: OSHA Asbestos Standards
entities.context: Regulatory framework relevant to exposure assessment

entities.name: International Agency for Research on Cancer
canonical_forms: International Agency for Research on Cancer

entities.name: BRCA1
entities.context: Relevant to ovarian cancer predisposition in talc litigation

entities.name: BRCA2
entities.context: Relevant to ovarian cancer predisposition in talc litigation

relationships.subject: e006
relationships.description: Asbestos exposure is associated with increased mesothelioma risk

relationships.subject: e004

relationships.subject: e011

relationships.subject: e015
relationships.description: BRCA1 mutations cause ovarian cancer predisposition

relationships.subject: e007
relationships.description: Talc exposure has been claimed to associate with ovarian cancer

relationships.subject: e010

relationships.subject: t001

relationships.subject: e004
relationships.description: BAP1 status may influence mesothelioma treatment response

context.business_context: Legal defense for asbestos and talc defendants requires timely awareness of scientific developments that impact causation arguments, expert testimony credibility, and case strategy. Genomic research increasingly provides alternative explanations for cancer development beyond environmental exposure.
context.time_sensitivity: High - new genomic findings can rapidly influence expert opinions and case strategies. Publications should be identified within 1-2 weeks of release to enable timely integration into ongoing cases.

signal_types.name: Germline Mutation Studies
signal_types.description: Studies identifying inherited genetic variants associated with mesothelioma or other cancer predisposition
examples: BAP1 germline mutation carriers and mesothelioma risk

signal_types.name: Somatic Mutation Landscapes
signal_types.description: Tumor sequencing studies characterizing acquired mutations in cancers

signal_types.name: Gene-Environment Interaction Studies
signal_types.description: Research on how genetic variants modify environmental exposure effects
examples: DNA repair gene variants and carcinogen exposure

signal_types.name: Exposure Biomarker Studies
signal_types.description: Research on molecular markers of asbestos or talc exposure

signal_types.name: Dose-Response Research
signal_types.description: Studies examining exposure thresholds and dose-response relationships

signal_types.name: Alternative Causation Studies
signal_types.description: Research on non-exposure mechanisms of cancer development
examples: Background cancer rates in unexposed populations

signal_types.name: Regulatory Updates
signal_types.description: Changes to exposure limits, classification decisions, or guidelines

signal_types.name: Methodology Advances
signal_types.description: New genomic or analytical methods relevant to causation assessment

signal_types.name: Expert Witness Publications
signal_types.description: Publications by known plaintiff or defense expert witnesses
examples: Review articles by key opinion leaders

temporal_scope.rationale: Genomic science advances rapidly. Recent publications (2020-present) are most relevant for current litigation, but 2015-2020 literature establishes the knowledge baseline that experts should reasonably have. Earlier literature primarily provides historical context.

journal_quality: Top-tier oncology journals (Nature Cancer, Cancer Cell, JCO)
other_criteria: Published in indexed journals (PubMed, Web of Science)
Disclosed funding sources and conflicts of interest
Relevant to human health (animal studies only if directly translatable)

coverage.completeness_requirement: Comprehensive monitoring of high-priority signal types (must_have) is required. Should_have signals should be captured when identified but not exhaustively searched. Nice_to_have signals are opportunistic additions.

inclusions.description: Genomic studies of mesothelioma regardless of reported exposure status
inclusions.rationale: Even studies not focused on asbestos may reveal genetic predisposition factors relevant to alternative causation

inclusions.description: Research on BAP1 and other mesothelioma-associated tumor suppressor genes
inclusions.rationale: Critical for establishing non-exposure causation pathways

inclusions.description: Studies examining individual susceptibility to asbestos or talc at genetic level
inclusions.rationale: May support arguments that disease results from individual genetic susceptibility to asbestos-related cancer rather than exposure per se

inclusions.description: Research on BRCA1/BRCA2 and ovarian cancer in context of talc litigation
inclusions.rationale: Essential for alternative causation arguments in talc-ovarian cancer cases

inclusions.description: Dose-response studies with focus on low-dose or threshold effects
inclusions.rationale: Supports arguments that plaintiff exposures were below causal thresholds

inclusions.description: Studies of spontaneous or background rates of mesothelioma and related cancers
inclusions.rationale: Establishes baseline risk without exposure, supporting alternative causation

inclusions.description: Publications by known plaintiff or defense expert witnesses
inclusions.rationale: Allows monitoring of expert positions and preparation for cross-examination

inclusions.description: IARC, OSHA, EPA, and other regulatory agency determinations
inclusions.rationale: Regulatory positions frequently cited in litigation

exclusions.description: Animal-only studies without clear human relevance
exclusions.rationale: Limited direct applicability to human litigation context
exceptions: Studies of mechanism translatable to humans
Studies explicitly cited in human health risk assessments

exclusions.description: In vitro studies without clinical or epidemiological context
exclusions.rationale: Cell culture findings often do not translate to human disease
exceptions: Mechanistic studies directly relevant to established human phenomena
Studies informing interpretation of human genomic data

exclusions.description: Studies focused solely on treatment efficacy without causation relevance
exclusions.rationale: Treatment research generally not relevant to causation litigation
exceptions: Treatment studies revealing insights about disease biology or genomics

exclusions.description: Studies of occupational exposures unrelated to asbestos or talc
exceptions: Studies providing methodological insights applicable to asbestos/talc research

exclusions.description: Genomic studies of cancers with no claimed link to asbestos or talc
exclusions.rationale: Too broad; must focus on relevant cancer types
exceptions: Other cancers if explicitly discussed in asbestos/talc context

edge_cases.description: Studies of asbestosis or other non-malignant asbestos-related diseases
edge_cases.conditions: Include if they provide insights into exposure assessment, dose-response, or individual susceptibility that inform cancer causation arguments
edge_cases.rationale: Non-malignant disease is generally out of scope, but may contain relevant exposure science

edge_cases.description: Genomic studies of mesothelioma that do not mention asbestos
edge_cases.rationale: May reveal genetic predisposition or alternative causation regardless of author focus on exposure

edge_cases.description: Studies of erionite or other non-asbestos mineral fibers
edge_cases.conditions: Include if they provide comparative insights or mechanistic understanding applicable to asbestos
edge_cases.rationale: Comparative carcinogen research may inform understanding of asbestos mechanisms

edge_cases.conditions: Include only if directly addressing dose-response, background rates, or alternative causation in ways that inform genomic interpretation
edge_cases.rationale: Epidemiology is relevant but should not dominate a genomics-focused monitoring service

edge_cases.description: Retracted articles or articles with published corrections
edge_cases.rationale: Important to track scientific controversies and corrected findings that may have litigation impact

edge_cases.description: Studies of talc contamination with asbestos
edge_cases.rationale: Directly relevant to both asbestos and talc litigation

edge_cases.description: Pharmacogenomic studies of chemotherapy response in mesothelioma
edge_cases.conditions: Unless they reveal insights about disease genomics or predisposition
edge_cases.rationale: Treatment pharmacogenomics generally not relevant to causation

edge_cases.description: Population genetics studies of cancer susceptibility in specific ethnic groups
edge_cases.conditions: Include if relevant to understanding variation in mesothelioma or related cancer risk
edge_cases.rationale: May inform understanding of baseline genetic risk in diverse plaintiff populations

extraction_metadata.extracted_from: Legal defense monitoring requirements document and genomics litigation strategy guidelines
extraction_metadata.review_notes: Configuration tailored for legal defense context with emphasis on genomic alternative causation theories. Balanced coverage of both asbestos and talc litigation needs.
